text: Hi everyone! I'm Fike (it's fee-kuh, doesn't rhyme with Nike) from Indonesia. I'm Affiliate Specialist/Communications at Saturday Drive, the team behind Ninja Forms and Caldera Forms. I work remotely since most of the team is in the US. Soo excited to meet you all :smile:

text:
Calling all SaaS content rockstars!!

Here's a project you'll love, which I'm very excited about.

After joggling many names, I settled for "Real SaaS Content."

A little background:

Ever since I narrowed my focus on becoming a nice blend of SaaS content strategist, product storyteller, and copywriter, I visited countless SaaS blogs, communities, and agencies in search of content on SaaS growth along those lines.

One thing always stood out for me.

Content that got the most shares (traffic & backlinks) where original stories of how a SaaS company drove growth. Some told by their founders or other executives. Others in the form of case studies.

Unfortunately, there was no directory I could easily go to swipe a collection of such content, focused exclusively on SaaS.

So I decided to create one.

And behold, a new Medium publication with the name, "<https://medium.com/real-saas-content|Real SaaS Content>."

I invite all SaaS content marketers here to repurpose original and case study-type of SaaS content on Medium through "Real SaaS Content."

Medium takes good care of duplicate content (and canonical) issues, so your content won't have any penalties when repurposed there.

Instead, you'll be bringing more eyeballs on your content (service or business).

Your content doesn't have to be fresh.

As long as its an original story of how a SaaS brand drove growth or in a case study format, we'll accept in on "Real SaaS Content."

Interested in giving your already-published SaaS content more bandwidth?

Message me for access.

attachments.title: Real SaaS Content – Medium
attachments.text: The best SaaS content marketing stories — to ignite real SaaS growth.

text: Great questions! I like this approach - The answer to your questions are very, and many - so I think that content could definitely help in this regard.

text:
<@URAV154AV> Agree with you 100% about the complexity of selling to enterprises vs. SMBs.

I think things are likely to get much harder for enterprise sales, too, as the spread of the coronavirus raises corporate concerns about business risk.

In my opinion, our content can't ignore the issue of risk in hopes it won't occur to our prospects. We have to address it head on, because it's moved to the front of their minds.

The more time, effort, and cost required to implement an enterprise solution, the greater the prospect's perception of risk.

When companies perceive risk and uncertainly, they're likely to opt to continue with the status quo.

To overcome this, SaaS vendors have 3 options:

1. Increase the buyer's perception of value to help offset their perception of risk. This requires value selling. 
2. Mitigate the buyer's perception of the risks of implementing your solution. 
3. Show how your solutions help them mitigate other risks they're concerned about. (Example, if you're Zoom, show how your solution enables prospects to do business without exposing your employees to the risks of travel.)
For companies that don't do all 3, I suspect a lot of already-long sales cycles will soon get even longer.

In my opinion, our content can't ignore the issue of risk in hopes it won't occur to our prospects. We have to address it head on, because it's moved to the front of their minds.

The more time, effort, and cost required to implement an enterprise solution, the greater the prospect's perception of risk.

When companies perceive risk and uncertainly, they're likely to opt to continue with the status quo.

To overcome this, SaaS vendors have 3 options:
Increase the buyer's perception of value to help offset their perception of risk. This requires value selling.
Mitigate the buyer's perception of the risks of implementing your solution.

Show how your solutions help them mitigate other risks they're concerned about. (Example, if you're Zoom, show how your solution enables prospects to do business without exposing your employees to the risks of travel.)
For companies that don't do all 3, I suspect a lot of already-long sales cycles will soon get even longer.
